speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Welcome to Contextualizing Feminist Voices, Teaching with the Global Feminisms Project.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: This series is focused on teaching, pedagogy, and uses of the archive in the context of the classroom.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Designed with a special emphasis on educators, in each episode you will learn from instructors

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: who have used the project's interviews in their courses, and about activities and resources

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: for incorporating the archive into your class.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Today, we will be joined by Dr. Abigail Stewart, who is the Sandra Schwartz Tangri Distinguished

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: University Professor of Psychology and Women's Studies at the University of Michigan.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Dr. Stewart has published many scholarly articles

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and several books focusing on feminist psychological research and the psychology of women's lives,

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: personalities, and adaptations to personal and social changes. She is a founder and current

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: project director of the Global Feminisms Project and consequently has over two decades of experience

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: teaching with this archive and its materials as it has developed

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: over time. Thank you so much for joining me today. I'm super excited to hear all about your extensive

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: experience teaching with these materials. Would you please briefly describe the course you use

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the archive in? I'm very happy to do this with you. I've taught a 300 level course, which means it's aimed at juniors and seniors called gender in global context.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And it was mostly designed to be taken by women's and gender study students.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: But because I'm also in the psychology department, I've taught it cross listed with psychology.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: For that reason, I included some theoretical material about how psychologists think

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: about individual lives in context. For example, theories that link individuals' development or age

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: with social historical events or theories of how generations differ. So those theories then were

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: among the things we thought about as we discussed the women's accounts in the interviews, along, of course, with feminist theories and theories about organizing and activism.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I taught the course in two 80-minute classes to about 25 upper division graduate students. The class combined short periods of my lecturing and mainly lots of activity and discussion in small groups

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and as a whole class. That sounds great. And how do you use the material in the archive?

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I have to say it was great. It's been one of my favorite classes ever to teach in my long career.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: I felt in terms of engaging with the archive that the most important thing for students to experience was actually engagement with the interviews and the women themselves.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: I was also eager to interrupt or prevent, ideally, any tendency either to exoticize women's experience in other cultures or to overgeneralize about experiences either across cultures or within

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: cultures. So one of the things I did was for each class to choose a few interviews that addressed

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: an issue like violence against women, or the impact of national revolutionary movements on

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the development of women's movements, or reproductive justice. I would pair interviews from a couple of countries so students could

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: think about how the different contexts influenced the issue and how the different women related to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the issue. For example, in one class, I had students compare the experience of the Indian

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: revolutionary movement as articulated by Veena Mazumdar with that of the Chinese

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: revolution by Wang Qingzhuang in China. Students also might compare the experience of two different

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: women within a single country. In this case, on that topic, in the case of Dora Maria Tellez

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and Sandra Ramos for Nicaragua, both involved with the revolution and with the women's movement,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: but very different experience. Students would be assigned in groups to read just one of the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: interviews very carefully and then to work together with people who read the other interview

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to identify key features of their experience that were common and that were different.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: The groups reported out to the whole class, and we jointly assembled a picture of each woman's

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: account and then could compare them and talk about the commonalities and differences.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That experience helped the students become good readers of the historical and political context

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: in the interviews, which was often hard for them to see

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: because, of course, they seemed like just one woman's story. But it fostered their ability to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: think about each of the national contexts in some depth. And most of all, of course, it allowed them

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to think about the unique life path of one woman. And for many of the students, the feedback I got was that they found

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: that process deeply meaningful and personally inspiring. That's incredibly powerful. I'm so

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: excited you're able to, you know, expand on all of those themes just through these

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: types of courses. And for these ends, what kind of assignments did you end up using?

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Well, there are quite a few, but I'll

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: talk about a couple. The first assignment for the course asked students to interview two women in

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: their own extended families who represented different generations, and then to identify

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: important features of the social political environment of those women's childhood,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: adolescence, young adulthood, and later adult stages stages so they could see how the environment

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: might have had different importance in their lives at different life stages

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: both engaging in interviewing themselves and using some of the theories offered in the course to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: analyze the experiences further deepen their understanding think, of both the method of interviewing

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and of analyzing interviews for understanding

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: an individual on the one hand

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and the social context on the other,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: which of course was the biggest game or goal of the course.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Here, I think students also in many cases,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: for the first time,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: recognize the way in which their own and their family members lives are embedded in social and historical processes.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That recognition of their own place in history was often really exciting to them to see.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Another assignment that I used was to invite students to work on developing accounts of

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: some of the women from the project for Wikipedia. This of course required teaching them a lot of skills

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: about how to interface with Wikipedia, which many of them were very excited to learn. Many of the

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: women in the archive are not yet in that resource, and this assignment not only allowed the students to learn how concisely to represent a

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: woman's contributions in terms that are appropriate for that context, but also to understand better

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the meaning of a primary source like the oral history itself, secondary sources about the woman

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and about the movements and the countries, And finally, a tertiary source like Wikipedia that depends on the first two.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Many students commented on how helpful to them it was to really understand for the first

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: time how tertiary resources can only be as good and as complete as the other two kinds

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: allow.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: That's critical.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And I love that these assignments keep expanding

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: the reach of feminist interviews and their power, especially in students' own lives.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: What do you think is most effective about the way you use the global feminism's materials

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: in these assignments? I think the first and most important thing is the women's own first-person

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: accounts in the oral history interviews. The students found those to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: be profoundly moving and inspiring, and in the end, I think that's the most important aspect

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: of using the archive in teaching. By examining several interviews from a single country over

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the course of the semester, students also readily saw that women or feminists in a single country were far from a homogeneous group.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Finally, I think many students saw the rest of the world and the U.S. in a different light. They saw

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the ways that women's movements have influenced each other and also have grappled with similar

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: issues in locally particular ways. I think in some ways it made it easier for them to imagine

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: themselves into a global context in new ways. The archive also allows students to engage in their

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: own research in unusual ways that can foster students' skill and confidence. I foregrounded

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: some of that with the two assignments I talked about, but another assignment was to ask students

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to choose a topic they cared about and identify at least two interviews from at least two countries that

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: address that topic and spell out how those interviews illuminate the topic. Students were

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: anxious about finding the right materials within the archive, but they ended up with some help,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and there are many assistances within the archive, like

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: keywords that point them in the right direction, to find the right materials.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: And they were thrilled to discover that they could offer new insight into an issue they

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: cared about based only on these materials.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Experiencing themselves as knowledge producers was very empowering to many students. It's also important

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: for them to hear feminists say things that are important to them, but that might be deeply

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: abhorrent to the students and to some other feminists. They need to be able to learn how to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: think about why it's important, not only for historians, but for all of us both to recognize that women's movement

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: activists are complex flawed human beings and that the history of the movements always includes

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: struggle not only with forces outside the movement but also within it encountering these issues in

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the interviews though sometimes painful helps students recognize that views and actions we may find deeply troublesome, as well as conflict and debate, are part of the women's movement and cannot be ignored or absent from the archive, but must be preserved and analyzed.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: preserved and analyzed. Wonderful. Do you have any advice for others about pitfalls to avoid in using the materials or any difficulties to watch out for? I think the main obstacle for faculty

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: to using the materials is our deeply ingrained anxiety about what we don't know, up to and

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: including how to pronounce activists' names. The sense of working

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: outside our comfort zones of knowledge is very daunting for faculty, even though we ask students

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: to do that every day. I actually think it's valuable to be limited in our knowledge and

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: learning in the same ways as the students, even if we may be more skilled at identifying information that

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: helps overcome our lack of knowledge. I tried very hard to position myself as a non-expert on any of

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: the countries or issues, which by the way was easy to do since I am a non-expert on any of them,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and I encouraged the students to work with me to learn as much as we could from the archive together.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Doing that allowed us to share our excitement, even a guide to pronunciation of names,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: maps, resources to pursue that provide contextual information. So it's easy for a faculty member to

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: overcome their lack of sense of knowledge if they're willing to give it a whirl.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: That's great. I think that's an incredibly valuable framing

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and it sounds like it really lent itself well

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: to all the activities you were able to do in your courses.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Thank you so much for taking the time

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: to share your experience and your expertise with us.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: It's been such a pleasure hearing about all the ways

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: you've been able to embed these materials

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: into your teaching

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and especially how they've gone on

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and affected students deeply

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: and their trajectories, hopefully as knowledge producers. Thank you. It's been my pleasure.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Thank you again to Dr. Abigail Stewart for joining us on the podcast today and sharing

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: her uniquely vast breadth of experience teaching with the archive's materials.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: We are sure her insights about student empowerment through their engagement with

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: the primary research materials in the archive and the opportunity to understand the complexities and pluralisms of feminisms across geography and

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: history will be invaluable to instructors of any course looking to engage with the Global Feminisms

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Project materials. Thank you for listening to this episode of Contextualizing Feminist Voices,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Teaching with the Global Feminisms Project, a podcast created by the Global Feminisms Project.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Teaching with the Global Feminisms Project, a podcast created by the Global Feminisms Project.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: The entire team hopes it will help you understand and incorporate the materials on the website into your class. If you liked this episode, check out the other podcasts in the series, as well as materials about countries, teaching resources, and interviews on the website. Thank you.
